title: Who will win the 2022 presidential election in Colombia?
preds:
Such a close election, from the perspective of polls and polling aggregates (despite the failures we've seen in polling in recent elections and all the blind spots), but also given other factors like the quick rise of Rodolfo Hernandez and the high rejection rate for Gustavo Petro. With no polling data in the last week, and no debate (Hernandez and his team didn't show up, didn't comply with court order) what can we look at that could possibly give an indication of what is most likely to turn the tide and in which direction? 
 Looking at headlines, international newspapers giving the main focus to the Hernandez phenomenon. On social media, I found it surprising to see posts from influential figures like writers, singers who are Petro supporters using a defeated tone, hinting at a Hernandez win and reproaching Hernandez voters. The overwhelming number of replies to such posts were in support of Hernandez and the majority were citing "miedo" or fear of Petro and the onset of a Venezuela style socialism (for which there is no evidence of. As much as Petro might have been close to Chavez 15 years ago, there's plenty of evidence in the work he has done since that that is not the model he would pursue). Support for Hernandez is not so much the drive but adversion towards his opponent. 
 So, to close the forecast, here's what is making me tilt the balance to give Petro the edge:
 - Google searches for Petro's proposals (including youtube) are again higher than Hernandez's. People supporting Petro believe he represents a better Colombia, while too many people supporting Hernandez do it because of a "anyone but Petro" sentiment. My bet is that the latter have less conviction and willingness to show up to the polls on Sunday if it's too hot or it's raining and in a close election that can make the difference.  - Young people's votes. Well-organized groups of young people are behind Petro in very significant numbers and this includes the young people, college students, who participated in protests and saw many of their friends injured or die on the streets killed by the government's brutal crack down. I think that sentiment will be strong and can make enough of a difference. 
 - Searches for Rodolfo Hernandez, including searches for "propuestas" and "programa de gobierno" hit quite a low in the past 7-10 days. Hernandez hasn't had much to offer in terms of proposals or program. He has said that his job will be to manage and hire the right people to run the different aspects of government.  But his anti corruption speech is very far reaching and his simplistic style in explaining government failures is very popular. He does manage a lot of information about running government and the problems with bureaucracies in Colombia. His engineering background also gives him a straight to the point, "minimalist" matter of fact. This has an impact on average people and his success in business adds to his appeal. Hernandez often said he will figure things out once he gets to the presidency and that he doesn't need to go out on the streets to campaign because he is managing the emotions of the people, adding that campaigns are too expensive because in Colombia, every headline or good word from the media has to be paid so he rather appeals to people emotions and for that he doesn't need to tour the country.  His supporters say they will vote for him because he is a business man who knows how to manage things and that they trust that while Petro inspires "miedo" or fear (almost 400,000 Venezuelans now live in Colombia after fleeing their home country and the "socialism" line of attack is at the forefront). That said, is Colombia ready for such a non traditional approach to campaigning? Doesn't Hernandez need to show up to the areas where he has the most support to consolidate? - The effort Petro's running mate, Francia Marquez, has made is very significant. I haven't seen such a vp candidate in Lat Am in a very long time. The campaign has taken advantage of her strengths and she's been traveling all over the country.  - Taken aback by the rejection rate of Petro in some circles and wondering how far reaching that could be but seeing signs that people with high rejection rate for Petro would vote blank or abstain. 
 - Looking at percentages of supporters of first round candidates who now support Petro. 
 - Taking a look at the latest developments, news regarding the campaign, the most notorious is the video of Hernandez entertaining foreign investors and lobbyist in a yacht, dozens of women in bikinis dancing with the guests. But for Hernandez supporters, such a video, as exploitative it can be (capitalizing on Colombia's reputation for exporting women, uncomfortably touching on issue re sexism, human trafficking) would be a source of pride or humor and also a symbol their 77 year old "viejito" (little old man nickname) is virile and with stamina.  I don't think it'll do much damage in those undecided or planning to vote blank. As a side note, Pfizer execs are denying they had reps at the yacht party. 
 Hernandez's blunder in which he said he'd welcome the virgin Mary and all the prostitutes that live in her neighborhood seem to have started a domino effect in which more and more people started noticing his gaffes. Another reason he may lose some people to blank votes. In some ways, he may be like Trump whose supporters are immune to his gaffes.  Unlike in 2018, not very confident about this forecast. Changed location on Twitter to Colombia to see buzz but this is till a tough one to predict. As Hernandez said, a lot of people have to be paid to say something good about you while campaigning. It's become harder to discern sincere, organic engagement than "influenced" The blank vote is the one that seems to be gaining most ground in the end.

No other polls have come out since I last updated (polls are prohibited 7 days before the election), then again polling wasn't very accurate on the first round. The election is still expected to be very close.  Haven't found reliable info on new support garnered by Petro.  Focus of media coverage leans towards Hernandez's rise in popularity and attacks against Petro's "socialist" or progressive proposals in a conservative country or the likelihood of Colombia going the way of Venezuela. Petro is often mentioned in relation to his guerrilla activities in his youth, past ties to Cuba and his closeness to Hugo Chavez (he now says that the Chavez model failed for linking it to oil revenues and for forgetting about its democratic principles). But he recently told Le Monde that his agenda would be considered as centrist in Europe while in a country like Colombia, his centrist agenda is seen as revolutionary (for things like seeking to create a pension system or having what are seen as radical ideas about environmental protections).  Social media indicators give Petro quite an advantage but 1) he's been around much longer, this is the third time he runs 2) social media engagement can be both positive and negative and thus not necessarily an accurate measure of acceptance or support. Google searches also favor Petro.  Investors, businesses, the party in power, are behind Hernandez, as well as the wealthy. Petro attracts more intellectuals, progressives, middle class while the poor seem to be split in their support.  This week, the WSJ editorial board called Petro "a former terrorist" not merely a former guerrilla member back in the 90s who went on to become a senator and also mayor of the capital, Bogota. Colombia has been the exception in Latin America in the last few decades in not veering towards leftist governments. That said, I was surprised to see the number of highly educated people, economists, that are against Petro, saying his proposals would take Colombia back to the 80s and offer nothing new.  The campaign saying that Petro would turn Colombia into another Venezuela has proven to be effective, but also is Petro's campaign for a "humane Colombia" as well as his running mate calls for "vivir sabroso" and her award winning environmental advocacy.  Both Petro and Hernandez sell themselves as anti establishment and are said to represent a change from the status quo but Petro's proposals to tax the wealthy, seize pension assets, introduce public health care, and ban fracking and new oil exploration -- replacing oil industry with tourism, are seen as a real threat by many. Hernandez has shown to barely know the country, and makes one gaffe after another, but seems less threatening to many. He made a fortune in real estate and construction and has promised to build minimalist homes for people in rural areas, a program that has given him much popularity. His supporters don't seem to care that he called Hitler his favorite thinker (to later say he meant to say Einstein). People chuckle and feel safer with a successful business man at the helm than with a "socialist" who they see as a threat to private enterprise.  For one, Hernandez's campaign seems messy, scrambled, much less sophisticated organizationally and it's hard to believe people will vote for 77 year old who is funny on Tik Tok and is very much a Trump like figure (yes, with a quasi messianic component).  Digging but haven't found an element that'd make tilt the balance and I can't believe people will vote for Hernandez is not a sound rationale. A judge ordered a presidential debate to be held before Sunday’s election. In Colombia candidates are said to often avoid going to debates when they are leading in polls and Hernandez would clearly be at a disadvantage against an experienced, more articulate candidate like Petro.  I will wait to see what happens at the debate to get a better feel for the last stretch.

It seems Colombians are quite interested in Rodolfo Hernandez. Quite a lot of talk that it doesn't warrant a 0% probability, in my judgement. I think the crowd median is gravely underestimating how close the race really is.

Sticking with Hernandez due to:1-polls being quite volatile and wide dispersion over last few weeks 2-Colombians historically electing more conservative presidents 3-Hernandez has lower rejection rate

-Polling average giving Hernandez the edge, some polls at statistical dead heat. Hernandez has had the strongest rise since the first round. -Following results from the first round, projections are showing Hernández would dominate in the Eje Cafetero (coffee growing land) and Antioquia regions (54% vs. 26%); in Columbia's central lands (51% vs. 23%) and at the south-center region (46% vs. 34%).
 -Petro would have the advantage in the capital, Bogotá (49% vs. 39%); in the Caribe region (48% vs. 33%) and in the Pacific region (57% vs. 23%) - coastal areas.
 -Other demographic data shows that the wealthy are more likely to support Rodolfo Hernández (52% vs. 40%), while the middle class would support Petro. The poorest sectors of society are showing an empate técnico or technical tie: 40% Hernández vs. 39% Petro - Source: CNN en Espanol -Rejection of progressive ideas in such a conservative country is benefiting Hernandez, a Trump like figure that is just as irreverent.  He fancies himself as el Rey del Tik Tok (King of Tik Tok which has quite a reach). His campaign announced today that his life has been threatened by Petro's campaign and is cancelling all public appearances. Hernandez was campaigning today in Miami but some people thought he had fled the country due to safety concerns. Also notable this week is the resurgence of news related to Hernandez's daughter who as kidnapped in Colombia in 2004 and believed to be dead. Hernandez said she had been kidnapped in 2009, while his son said it was in 2004 and that she was kidnapped and killed by the ELN, then accused another guerilla group. All while the press leads with "ex-guerrillero Gustavo Petro" It's quite a contrast.  Hernandez also said the solution to the drug problem was to provide free drugs to addicts and that he had plans to do so. Meanwhile, he is being investigated for corruption while he was mayor of Bucaramanga, in relation for a $2 million bribe for public contracts involving his son. Hernandez is on tape made public by the district attorney saying "that they lay doesn't matter" but not even that seems to have an effect on his followers/ All these controversies have kept him dominating headlines and social media engagement.   -Petro on the other hand is relying on his message of "humane" Colombia to reach voters and is on the defensive -- he was part of a guerilla group, M-19, disbanded in 1990 and was mayor of the capital, Bogota, and senator since then but he has not been forgiven -- while Hernandez leads engagement. Supporters of 4th place candidate, Sergio Fajardo, and his vp running mate, are now supporting Petro, which means a part of the center right may vote for Petro.    This is the third time Petro runs for president, will he have AMLO's luck? It's uncertain. The campaign behind Hernandez after the first round is very strong and well-organized. The traditional right, the party in power who represent Uribismo, and their candidate, Federico Gutierrez, are now supporting Hernandez.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/06/07/colombia-rodolfo-hernandez/?utm_source=twitter&utm_campaign=wp_main&utm_medium=social

Hernandez does not even have a proper party or organization behind him, and his crowd/campaign had pretty poor results in previous elections. https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liga_de_Gobernantes_Anticorrupci%C3%B3n#Resultados_Electorales I wouldn't be surprised if recent opinion polling that sees him as front runner turn out to be manipulated and/or bought artefacts (he's not inside the media business like e.g. Silvio Berlusconi, but also made a fortune in construction; perhaps he has influential friends who own media outlets). I'm not sure he has a party program, at least he is said to have avoided public debates and thus discussion about any programs. "At first, his videos on social media platforms like TikTok caused amusement and he was thought to stand little chance against his better-known rivals.[...] The third-placed candidate, Fico Gutiérrez, has already endorsed Mr Hernández and there is a strong campaign by right-wing forces urging voters 'to keep Petro out' [...] Speaking after his first-round win, Mr Petro sounded defensive. 'Corruption isn't fought with TikTok slogans, even if some very respectable people think so,' he said clearly alluding to his rival for the presidency. ."  [ https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-61631964 ] One thing's for certain: if Hernandez wins, corruption will flourish and the fragile society and peace will implode, just like in Silvio Berlusconi's Italy and Donald Trump's MAGA state. The mafia is sharpening their knives already. His party ironically goes by the name of "anti-corruption league (LIGA)" - well, if you're poiting a finger at someone, three fingers point back at you. I think (and I hope) that Colombians will be too smart to fall for that doter billionaire Hernandez' line.

Pretty close race according to latest second round opinion polls; however, being a Trump-style populist billionaire appeasing to the poor, Hernandez seems to have a very stupid fragile business plan. https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elecciones_presidenciales_de_Colombia_de_2022#Segunda_vuelta_2

First round Colombian election results:
 Gustavo Petro 40.33%
 Rodolfo Hernandez  28.15%
 Federico Gutierrez 23.92%
 Sergio Fajardo 4.20% In 2018, Iván Duque received 54.03% while Petro got 41.77%.  The campaign against Petro is even more brutal than what it was in 2018. His running mate is Francia Marquez, a Black woman, environmental activist, lawyer, feminist, former housemaid, winner of the Goldman Prize, but haven't seen much indication as to how much Ms Marquez helps his chances of winning. I would think she will energize quite a few marginalized communities. On this second round, Petro is running directly against Rodolfo Hernandez, a populist, very Trump-like figure who is defying expectations as he rises in the polls despite saying things like "Hitler is his favorite thinker," mocking charging high interest on the poor for over 15 years, saying women should not be in government and should only support gov from the home. Colombia is a conservative country and it's not clear that much has changed since 2018 to catapult Petro to the presidency. Many believe he reached his peak at the first round and is very difficult to get the support he needs to win it. Voter turn out for the first round was only 45% (53% for the first and second rounds in 2018) Duque led by 13-14 points over Petro in both first and second rounds in 2018. So Petro did make some lead way since then but only by about 4%.  Will have to see which of the first round candidates will turn the supporters to Petro. So far, most of what I've seen is going toward's Hernandez.  As for latest polls, John Ottis on Twiter, who writes for both NPR, WSJ, reported that "for the first time in Colombia's presidential race, Gustavo Petro is NOT the frontrunner" linking to a poll that showed Petro trailing Rodolfo Hernández 41%-39%. "Colombians want an outsider and, by comparison, Petro is old news"  https://eltiempo.com/elecciones-2022/presidencia/encuesta-presidencial-segunda-vuelta-rodolfo-adelante-de-petro-676660 a través de 
 Other polls say there is a tie. Either way, it's a remarkable ascent for Hernandez given the percentage that he received on the first round.  Also notable, so much of the international press is focusing on Petro's leftist, progressive proposals and his past as a former guerilla than in Hernandez. Most of the negative highlights are for Petro.

Hernandez is hardly a"Trump of the Tropics." More like a John Major ora Jacques Chirac when he was a Prime Minister.  The old school anti-communist fear factor and criminal cartels make the second round very problematic.
Runoff very likely between Petro and Hernández: https://resultados.registraduria.gov.co/presidente/0/colombia
If baddies recently annouced "campaign truce" holds, its a done deal.

A platform based on taxing the rich resonates in Colombia.   But why Petro of all those who speak populese?   Maybe bc he manages to strike fear in the hearts of investors all the while sporting a fashion sense that can only be described angsty-economist-at-happy-hour.

Petro is leading comfortably in the polls and gaining. A runoff is the most likely outcome, with Petro and Gutierrez. Petro will most likely get the anti-establishment votes of Hernandez, while the Hernanes voters will probably skew slightly towards Gutierrez. Betancourt’s will most likely skew towards Petro. That plus the macro-trend of a movement back towards leftism (see Chile) gives the advantage to Petro.
Recent polling stats in Latin America. Czech them out here... https://eldeber.com.bo/mundo/candidato-petro-lidera-la-carrera-presidencial-en-colombia-segun-encuesta_275525
Adjusting to favor of Petro a little more than my last estimate following latest polls, but still maintaining out of consensus view since the gap between the candidates is narrower than it has been.

Recent polls showing Gutierrez continues to catch up.  In addition, following previous commentary about country historically electing more conservative governments, especially relative to the rest of South America.
I know Petro is winning latest polls, but I'm seeing how much Gutierrez has climbed and keeping in mind the country historically voting in right of center presidents...
Trending this way if you look at El Espectador and other Colombian online and print organs.
Hard to beat a populist candidate in a third world country

- Petro and Fajardo have been caught up in issues involving intentional delays to a hydroelectric plant that could produce 17% of the countries power
- Fajardo and others are being held responsible for >$1B in damages due to the delay
- Petro is famous and he knows how to use his fame to gain attention
- Fajardo is up on embezzlement charges from his time as governor for writing contracts in USD to the benefit of a third party
- Galan is young, ambitious, and anti-cartel. This is why he stands a very small chance of winning
- Hernandez has a rocky past in his time as Mayor and is not known old and unknown to many

Read this article from 2017 Americas Quarterly which offers helpful bckd. Petro compares himself to Pepe Mujica, a 1960s Uruguayan guerrilla leader, and later president. But Uruguay's military is quite different (and less restless) than Colombia's, (and those Colombia's military hold influence with).  The article 
 https://www.americasquarterly.org/fulltextarticle/whos-afraid-of-gustavo-petro/

Colombians learned something about choosing unknown presidents. Fajardo, Gaviria, and Galan's speeches are too ahead of their time. Federico Gutiérrez is mainly popular among people from Antioquia. Rodolfo Hernández can make a lot of noise but nothing more. In Colombia, the empty vote is a candidate too. Petro, with patience, has been constructing a solid and faithful voter base. The pandemic, the left-wing trend, and a weak right-wing chased by corruption scandals are just catalysts. In any case, maybe I'm wrong.

In South America there is a trend for left-wing politicians and politics -- Peru, then Chile, I believe that Colombia will follow the suit and Gustavo Petro shows the major popular support according to all latest polls -- https://www.valoraanalitik.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/encuesta-invamer-1.pdf
Fajardo's strong across the board Medellin and Antioquia connections could cause problems for the leftist-populist Petro.

Assuming its Petro vs. a center-left (Fajardo) or center-right (Hernandez) with an edge to Petro due to polling/current support.   Sources:
https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2021/12/11/despite-the-polls-a-centrist-could-win-colombias-election-in-may
https://www.semana.com/nacion/articulo/despego-rodolfo-hernandez-la-segunda-vuelta-presidencial-podria-ser-entre-el-y-gustavo-petro/202158/
Based on December polls Petro is ahead with 42%of the electoral which almost de double of the next candidate who is Sergio Fajardo.
Youth and others frustrated with conservative rulers will swing left as other South American voters are doing. Bios are here https://americasquarterly.org/article/meet-the-candidates-colombia/

As others have said,at this point in time it doesn’t seem like there will be a clear winner the first round. Gustavo Petro (runner up 2018) is doing his best to keep his name in the public on a daily basis and is making moves as if he’s going to win (consolidating political support with the Historical Pact). Seems to be running a strong social network awareness machine compared to others running. Currently polling the highest amongst peers. October article breaking down candidates 
https://www.semana.com/nacion/articulo/petro-y-los-enanitos-encuesta-presidencial-de-semana-revela-su-sorprendente-ventaja-frente-a-sus-rivales/202149/ Nov article on how the elections “could” shake out
https://www.semana.com/nacion/articulo/asi-se-mueven-las-fichas-para-las-elecciones-del-2022/202035/ Dec video talking about polls
https://www.semana.com/nacion/articulo/tik-tak-que-tan-acertadas-pueden-ser-las-encuestas-antes-de-marzo/202156/
Petro may win first round, but it will be hard for him to win second round.

Neither of the candidates is likely to have a majority in the first round which is going to necessitate a second round-election.
Arithmetics of Party Alliances will do it, "Pacto Histórico por Colombia" being the alliance with the most parties under their tent.
https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elecciones_presidenciales_de_Colombia_de_2022#Pacto_Hist%C3%B3rico_por_Colombia
